questions.question: An architect is testing how the angle of a solar panel affects the amount of electricity generated per hour. In this experiment, what is the 'amount of electricity generated' called?
questions.explanation: The dependent variable is the factor that is measured or observed in response to changes in the independent variable. Here, the amount of electricity is measured in response to changes in the panel angle.

questions.question: A student proposes: 'If the mass of a pendulum bob is increased, then its period of oscillation will remain the same.' Name this step of the scientific method.
questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a testable prediction stated in an 'If...then...' format about the relationship between variables.

questions.question: The thickness of a specialized graphene sheet is $0.000000000334\text{ m}$. Express this in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 10 places to the right: $0.000000000334 = 3.34 \times 10^{-10}\text{ m}$.

questions.question: The total number of pixels in a high-resolution satellite map is $128,400,000,000,000$. Express this number in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 14 places to the left: $128,400,000,000,000 = 1.284 \times 10^{14}$.

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.00090200\text{ kg}$?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits $9$, $0$, $2$, $0$, and the trailing $0$ are significant, giving a total of 5 significant figures.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a fundamental (base) quantity in physics.
questions.explanation: Amount of substance (measured in moles) is one of the seven SI base quantities. Momentum and power are derived quantities.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a derived quantity.
questions.explanation: Pressure is derived from force and area ($P = F/A$). Luminous intensity and time are fundamental quantities.

questions.question: Which of these is a fundamental SI unit?
questions.explanation: The second (s) is the SI base unit for time. Volt and Ohm are derived units.

questions.question: Which of these is a derived SI unit?
questions.explanation: The Joule (J) is a derived unit for energy ($1\text{ J} = 1\text{ N·m}$). Kelvin and kilogram are fundamental SI units.

questions.question: A high-speed maglev train travels at a speed of $432\text{ km/h}$. Convert this speed to meters per second ($\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: To convert from km/h to m/s, divide by $3.6$: $432 \div 3.6 = 120\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A peregrine falcon dives at a speed of $90\text{ m/s}$. What is its speed in kilometers per hour ($\text{km/h}$)?
questions.explanation: To convert from m/s to km/h, multiply by $3.6$: $90 \times 3.6 = 324\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: The width of a surgical suture is $0.00018\text{ m}$. How many millimeters (mm) is this width?
A roll of industrial wire is $62{,}500\text{ mm}$ long. Express this length in meters.
A classroom whiteboard is $244\text{ cm}$ wide. What is this width in meters?
questions.explanation: $1\text{ m} = 100\text{ cm}$, so $244\text{ cm} = 244 \div 100 = 2.44\text{ m}$.

questions.question: An acoustic panel has an area of $5{,}400\text{ cm}^2$. Convert this area to square meters ($\text{m}^2$).
A delivery robot travels $800\text{ m}$ due West, then immediately turns around and travels $200\text{ m}$ due East. The entire trip takes $120\text{ s}$. Calculate the robot's average velocity.
questions.explanation: Displacement is $800\text{ m}$ West minus $200\text{ m}$ East, which equals $600\text{ m}$ West. Average velocity $= \text{displacement} / \text{time} = 600\text{ m} / 120\text{ s} = 5\text{ m/s}$ West.

questions.question: A scooter increases its velocity uniformly from $2\text{ m/s}$ to $18\text{ m/s}$ in $4\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the scooter's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration is calculated using $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \frac{18 - 2}{4} = \frac{16}{4} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A cyclist slows down uniformly from $15\text{ m/s}$ to $3\text{ m/s}$ in $3\text{ s}$. Calculate the acceleration of the cyclist, including the correct sign to indicate direction.
questions.explanation: $a = \frac{3 - 15}{3} = \frac{-12}{3} = -4\text{ m/s}^2$. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the direction opposite to the velocity (deceleration).

questions.question: A dog runs $50\text{ m}$ away from its owner and then $50\text{ m}$ back to the owner. The entire trip takes $20\text{ s}$. Calculate the dog's average speed and the magnitude of its average velocity.
questions.explanation: Average speed is total distance over time: $\frac{100\text{ m}}{20\text{ s}} = 5\text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is displacement over time: displacement $= 0$ (returns to start), so velocity $= 0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A hiker walks $8\text{ km}$ due East and then $6\text{ km}$ due South. Calculate the total distance traveled and the magnitude of the hiker's displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: Total distance is the sum of the path lengths: $8 + 6 = 14\text{ km}$. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish, found using the Pythagorean theorem: $\sqrt{8^2 + 6^2} = \sqrt{64 + 36} = \sqrt{100} = 10\text{ km}$.

questions.question: A luggage belt at an airport moves at a constant speed of $0.8\text{ m/s}$ in a straight line. Describe the type of motion.
questions.explanation: Constant speed in a straight line indicates uniform motion with zero acceleration.

questions.question: On a displacement-time graph, the line is straight and sloping downward toward the time axis (x-axis). Describe the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation: A straight line with a constant negative slope on a displacement-time graph indicates uniform negative velocity (the object is moving backward at a constant speed).

questions.question: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $+12\text{ m/s}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means the velocity is constant (not changing). Therefore, the acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A server carries a tray of drinks forward at a constant speed. When the server stops suddenly, the drinks tip forward. Name the property of the drinks that is responsible for this.
questions.explanation: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. The drinks tend to continue moving forward due to inertia when the server stops.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $20\text{ kg}$ lawnmower at $3.5\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's Second Law: $F = ma = 20\text{ kg} \times 3.5\text{ m/s}^2 = 70\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person pushes against a wall with a force of $50\text{ N}$. According to Newton's Third Law, what is the magnitude of the force the wall exerts back on the person?
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, the wall exerts a force of $50\text{ N}$ back on the person.

questions.question: Calculate the weight of a $15\text{ kg}$ object on Earth, where the acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Weight is given by $W = mg = 15\text{ kg} \times 9.8\text{ m/s}^2 = 147\text{ N}$.

questions.question: An object weighs $180\text{ N}$ on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $6\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the mass of the object?
questions.explanation: From $W = mg$, the mass is $m = \frac{W}{g} = \frac{180\text{ N}}{6\text{ m/s}^2} = 30\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $20\text{ kg}$ box is resting on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor is $0.45$. Calculate the force of friction acting on the box if it is sliding. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: The friction force is $f = \mu N = \mu mg = 0.45 \times 20 \times 10 = 90\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the friction force acting on a sliding object is $40\text{ N}$ and the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.2$, what is the mass of the object? ($g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Using $f = \mu mg$, we solve for mass: $m = \frac{f}{\mu g} = \frac{40}{0.2 \times 10} = 20\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $2\text{ kg}$ book is placed on top of an $8\text{ kg}$ cart. A horizontal force of $50\text{ N}$ is applied to the cart. Ignoring friction, find the acceleration of the cart and book together.
questions.explanation: The total mass being accelerated is $2\text{ kg} + 8\text{ kg} = 10\text{ kg}$. Using Newton's Second Law, $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{50\text{ N}}{10\text{ kg}} = 5\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two blocks, one with a mass of $12\text{ kg}$ and the other with a mass of $28\text{ kg}$, are connected by a rope and pulled by a $160\text{ N}$ force across a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the system?
questions.explanation: The total mass is $12 + 28 = 40\text{ kg}$. The acceleration is $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{160\text{ N}}{40\text{ kg}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A mop is pushed across a floor at a constant speed by a force of $24\text{ N}$. What is the magnitude of the friction force acting on the mop?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means the net force is zero. Therefore, the applied force must exactly balance the friction force: $f_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} = 24\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $150\text{ N}$ force pulls a $20\text{ kg}$ object across a surface. The force of friction opposing the motion is $30\text{ N}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: The net force is $F_{\text{net}} = 150\text{ N} - 30\text{ N} = 120\text{ N}$. Acceleration is $a = \frac{F_{\text{net}}}{m} = \frac{120\text{ N}}{20\text{ kg}} = 6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $200\text{ N}$ horizontal force pushes a $25\text{ kg}$ block, causing it to accelerate at $4\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
questions.explanation: The net force required to produce the acceleration is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 25 \times 4 = 100\text{ N}$. Since the applied force is $200\text{ N}$, the friction force must be $F_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} - F_{\text{net}} = 200 - 100 = 100\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A swimmer moves through the water at a constant speed, overcoming $15\text{ N}$ of water drag and $5\text{ N}$ of internal resistance from their body. Find the total applied force provided by the swimmer.
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the applied force must balance the total resistance: $F_{\text{app}} = 15\text{ N} + 5\text{ N} = 20\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A tractor provides a forward force of $3{,}000\text{ N}$. The soil friction acting on the plow is $2{,}400\text{ N}$. If the tractor moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the air drag?
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force is zero. Therefore, the thrust must equal the sum of the resistive forces: $3{,}000 = 2{,}400 + F_{\text{drag}}$, so $F_{\text{drag}} = 3{,}000 - 2{,}400 = 600\text{ N}$.

questions.question: The applied force on an object is $480\text{ N}$, and the air drag acting on it is $310\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the mechanical friction?
questions.explanation: For constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the sum of resistive forces must equal the applied force. Therefore, $480 = 310 + f_{\text{friction}}$, so $f_{\text{friction}} = 480 - 310 = 170\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A gardener is slowly lowering a watering can to the ground at a constant speed. Is the work done by the gardener on the can positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The gardener exerts an upward force on the can to control its descent, while the can's displacement is downward. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by the gardener is negative.

questions.question: A child pulls a toy car along the floor with a string, and the car moves in the direction of the pulling force. Is the work done by the child on the car positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The child exerts a force on the car in the direction of the car's displacement. Force and displacement are in the same direction, so the work done by the child is positive.

questions.question: A $0.5\text{ kg}$ ornament is hanging from a tree branch $2\text{ m}$ above the ground. Calculate the ornament's gravitational potential energy relative to the ground. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is given by $GPE = mgh = 0.5\text{ kg} \times 10\text{ m/s}^2 \times 2\text{ m} = 10\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $1.2\text{ kg}$ bird is flying at a speed of $10\text{ m/s}$. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is calculated using $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(1.2)(10)^2 = 0.6 \times 100 = 60\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball has $200\text{ J}$ of gravitational potential energy at the top of a ramp. At the bottom of the ramp, it has $175\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy. How much energy was converted to heat due to friction?
questions.explanation: The energy lost to heat is the difference between the initial potential energy and the final kinetic energy: $200\text{ J} - 175\text{ J} = 25\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car accelerates while driving on a flat road. Describe the changes in its kinetic energy (KE) and gravitational potential energy (PE).
options: KE is increasing; PE is constant
KE is increasing; PE is increasing
KE is constant; PE is constant
KE is increasing; PE is decreasing
questions.explanation: As the car accelerates, its speed increases, so its KE is increasing. Since it is on a flat road, its height (and thus its PE) is constant.

questions.question: A rock is thrown vertically upward into the air. Ignoring air resistance, describe the energy transition as it rises.
options: Both KE and PE are increasing
Both KE and PE are decreasing
questions.explanation: As the rock rises, its speed decreases (so KE decreases) and its height increases (so PE increases). Kinetic energy is being converted into potential energy.

questions.question: A satellite moves at a constant speed in a circular orbit around the Earth. Describe its kinetic energy (KE).
questions.explanation: Constant speed means the magnitude of velocity is constant, so the kinetic energy is constant.

questions.question: An unstretched spring has a length of $10\text{ cm}$. When a mass is added, the spring reaches a total length of $16.5\text{ cm}$. Calculate the extension of the spring.
questions.explanation: The extension is the increase in length: $\text{extension} = \text{final length} - \text{original length} = 16.5\text{ cm} - 10\text{ cm} = 6.5\text{ cm}$.

questions.question: An engine uses $4{,}000\text{ J}$ of energy from fuel to produce $3{,}000\text{ J}$ of useful work. Calculate the efficiency of the engine.
questions.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful work output to energy input, expressed as a percentage: $\left(\frac{3{,}000}{4{,}000}\right) \times 100\% = 75\%$.

questions.question: Calculate the total resistance of three resistors with resistances $10\,\Omega$, $30\,\Omega$, and $60\,\Omega$ when they are connected in series.
questions.explanation: For resistors in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances: $R_{\text{total}} = 10 + 30 + 60 = 100\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of three identical $90\,\Omega$ resistors when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{R}{n} = \frac{90\,\Omega}{3} = 30\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $20\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. This combination is then connected in parallel with a single $10\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The series pair has a resistance of $20 + 20 = 40\,\Omega$. This $40\,\Omega$ resistor is in parallel with the $10\,\Omega$ resistor. The equivalent resistance is given by $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{40} + \frac{1}{10} = \frac{1+4}{40} = \frac{5}{40} = \frac{1}{8} \rightarrow R = 8\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $40\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is then connected in series with a $20\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel pair has an equivalent resistance of $\frac{40}{2} = 20\,\Omega$. Adding this in series with the $20\,\Omega$ resistor gives a total of $20 + 20 = 40\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the electrostatic force between two point charges of $2\,\mu\text{C}$ and $4\,\mu\text{C}$ separated by a distance of $0.02\text{ m}$ in a vacuum. (Use $k = 9 \times 10^9\text{ N·m}^2/\text{C}^2$).
questions.explanation: Using Coulomb's Law, $F = k\frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2} = (9 \times 10^9)\frac{(2 \times 10^{-6})(4 \times 10^{-6})}{(0.02)^2} = \frac{72 \times 10^{-3}}{4 \times 10^{-4}} = 180\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the distance between two point charges is halved ($r \rightarrow r/2$) and the magnitude of one charge is doubled ($Q \rightarrow 2Q$), while the other charge remains the same, how does the magnitude of the original electrostatic force $F$ change?
questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states $F \propto \frac{q}{r^2}$. Doubling one charge multiplies the force by $2$. Halving the distance multiplies the force by $1/(1/2)^2 = 4$. The net factor is $2 \times 4 = 8$, so the new force is $8F$.

questions.question: Three identical positive point charges are placed in a straight line with equal spacing between them. Charge A is on the left, B is in the middle, and C is on the right. What is the direction of the net electrostatic force on the leftmost charge (A)?
options: Toward the left (repelled by B and C)
Toward the right (repelled by B and C)
Zero (the forces from B and C cancel out)
questions.explanation: Charge B ($+Q$) repels charge A ($+Q$) to the left. Charge C ($+Q$) also repels charge A ($+Q$) to the left. Both forces on A are in the same direction (to the left), so the net force on A is to the left.

questions.question: A $30\,\Omega$ light bulb is connected to a $120\text{ V}$ household outlet. Find the current flowing through it.
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law gives the current as $I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{120\text{ V}}{30\,\Omega} = 4\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $15\,\Omega$ resistor has a current of $2\text{ A}$ flowing through it. What is the power dissipated by the resistor?
questions.explanation: Electrical power can be calculated using $P = I^2R = (2\text{ A})^2 \times 15\,\Omega = 4 \times 15 = 60\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A $20\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $60\text{ V}$ power supply. Find the power dissipated by the resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, we get $P = \frac{(60\text{ V})^2}{20\,\Omega} = \frac{3{,}600}{20} = 180\text{ W}$.

questions.question: If a charge of $1{,}200\text{ C}$ flows through a conductor in a time of $10$ minutes, what is the current?
questions.explanation: First convert time to seconds: $10$ minutes $= 600\text{ s}$. Electric current is $I = \frac{Q}{t} = \frac{1{,}200\text{ C}}{600\text{ s}} = 2\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A microscope slide has a thickness of $0.00125\text{ m}$. Express this thickness in millimeters (mm).
